attachments.title: Julia package manager
attachments.text: Hi! I am new to Julia and GitHub. I cannot get the program PotentialFlow to run. The instructions from the site are: PotentialFlow can be installed using the Julia package manager. From the Julia REPL, type ] to enter the Pkg REPL mode and run pkg> add PotentialFlow I tried that after downloading the 64-bit (installer) version on my windows PC. Then I ran pkg> add PotentialFlow and it did not work. Can anyone help me? Thank you. This is for a school project. Our teacher came up with this i...

messages.text:
Do we have a (mostly) complete listing of all the Julia discussion / help / information forums somewhere?
Between GitHub (comments on PRs and Issues), Gitter, IRC chat, Discourse, various Discord servers, Slack, StackOverflow, Reddit, ‚Ä¶ now GitHub community, it seems difficult at times to know where to go.

attachments.title: Software Carpentry lessons with Julia
attachments.text: Software Carpentry is a project to teach basics of programming in the context of research computing. The target audience includes both students and researchers. The current curriculum includes the use of Unix shell, version control with Git, and some lessons with Python and R. To be clear, these lessons aren‚Äôt meant to be in any way exhaustive and the programming language used during the lessons is more a mean through which to deliver to attendees good programming practices. A few people are...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: Software Carpentry lessons with Julia

messages.text:
Hi everyone,
I am a beginner developer and in the process of making a
 library in rust i faced a problem that you can't store fuctions in
collection as functions are not first class object. And then i find out
about juila .Now i have written a 30 line library. please review this
library and provide suggestions for me to improvement. I have just
started julia programming yesterday.
imghdr is an a inbuilt module of python for detection of image type.
repo link:
<https://github.com/Agent-Hellboy/ImgHdr.jl>

messages.text:
Anyone have thoughts on adding to the description of <#C6FGJ8REC|appreciation> something like: _‚Äútip: Its best if you can appreciate (`@`) people for doing things, rather than just appreciating things being done.‚Äù_
I mean all appreciation is good, but the best appreciation is when we appreciate people be name so everyone knows how cool they are (and so they themselves know they are being appreciated).
I.e.  rather than just _‚ÄúI appreciate that the FooBar package is so flexible.‚Äú_, its best to at least add _‚Äúthanks `@author`‚Äù_.
I feel like mostly people do do this already, and it is good and so we should encourage people to keep doing it.

elements.text: Anyone have thoughts on adding to the description of
something like:
‚Äútip: Its best if you can appreciate (
) people for doing things, rather than just appreciating things being done.‚Äù

I mean all appreciation is good, but the best appreciation is when we appreciate people be name so everyone knows how cool they are (and so they themselves know they are being appreciated).
I.e.  rather than just
‚ÄúI appreciate that the FooBar package is so flexible.‚Äú
, its best to at least add
‚Äúthanks
@author
‚Äù

.
I feel like mostly people do do this already, and it is good and so we should encourage people to keep doing it.

messages.text: I think if we're doing it already there's not much reason to formalize it. Sometimes people don't know who did something, so putting a message like that may make some timid people feel like they *can't* post their appreciation. If someone omits a name, often someone else comes along and pings the appropriate person anyways.

elements.text: I think if we're doing it already there's not much reason to formalize it. Sometimes people don't know who did something, so putting a message like that may make some timid people feel like they
can't
post their appreciation. If someone omits a name, often someone else comes along and pings the appropriate person anyways.

messages.text: In general I guess I feel a bit of a worry that as the community grows, if we don‚Äôt write some things down and positively reinforce the aspects of our community they might get lost.

elements.text: In general I guess I feel a bit of a worry that as the community grows, if we don‚Äôt write some things down and positively reinforce the aspects of our community they might get lost.

messages.text: Maybe i don‚Äôt have to worry, since people constantly are modelling the good behavour.

elements.text: Maybe i don‚Äôt have to worry, since people constantly are modelling the good behavour.

messages.text:
Sometimes, what you appreciate greatly was from the efforts of a large group, so it‚Äôs hard to just name one (or even a few)
In those cases, the people who contributed will recognize  the appreciation for things they worked on, IMO.
I do agree, if it‚Äôs a small number, naming them is good (although there are some people who are so appreciated, the constant pinging *might* get annoying! :joy:)

messages.text:
This might be a nice opportunity for a "why julia" type presentation:

> Hi everyone! We are seeking proposals for participant-led mini-workshops and social programme activities as part of the Software Sustainability Institute's Collaborations Workshop 2021 (CW21), which will take place online from Tuesday, 30 March to Thursday, 1 April 2021! Are you interested in running a 30 minute session to demonstrate a particular software product, approach or standard? Deliver specific training or an interactive tutorial? Conduct information gathering or explore a topic? Or do you have an idea for a conference networking or social activity that you would like to facilitate? The deadline for submissions is 31 January 2021.
> 
> CW21 will bring together researchers, developers, innovators, managers, funders, publishers, policy makers, leaders and educators to explore best practices and the future of research software with a focus on the themes of FAIR Research Software, Diversity & Inclusion and Software Sustainability. To find out more information including registration, financial assistance, agenda, call for submissions and how to sponsor the unconference, please visit the CW21 website: <http://bit.ly/ssi-cw21|http://bit.ly/ssi-cw21>

elements.text: This might be a nice opportunity for a "why julia" type presentation:

Hi everyone! We are seeking proposals for participant-led mini-workshops and social programme activities as part of the Software Sustainability Institute's Collaborations Workshop 2021 (CW21), which will take place online from Tuesday, 30 March to Thursday, 1 April 2021! Are you interested in running a 30 minute session to demonstrate a particular software product, approach or standard? Deliver specific training or an interactive tutorial? Conduct information gathering or explore a topic? Or do you have an idea for a conference networking or social activity that you would like to facilitate? The deadline for submissions is 31 January 2021.

CW21 will bring together researchers, developers, innovators, managers, funders, publishers, policy makers, leaders and educators to explore best practices and the future of research software with a focus on the themes of FAIR Research Software, Diversity & Inclusion and Software Sustainability. To find out more information including registration, financial assistance, agenda, call for submissions and how to sponsor the unconference, please visit the CW21 website:
http://bit.ly/ssi-cw21

messages.text: Would love to hear thoughts: <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/bridging-slacks-helpdesk-and-discourse-proposal-feedback-welcome/53554>

attachments.title: Bridging Slack's #Helpdesk and Discourse (Proposal, feedback welcome!)
attachments.text: Hey all, following up on this proposal: #Helpdesk channel on Slack (proposal to close the channel) and a thread here: I‚Äôve heard a number of people say Julia is not mainstream because it doesn‚Äôt have many stackoverflow questions answered but they don‚Äôt know about discourse, I decided to work actively on these ideas to look into bridging Slack and Discourse. It turns out that it is indeed possible and pretty straightforward. I setup some integrations with Zapier (and previously made a version wi...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: Bridging Slack's #Helpdesk and Discourse (Proposal, feedback welcome!)

So we are looking for a Julia speaker where he/she can give a 30min - 60min lecture. We will be very happy to have you on board. I tried but right now I am not that much comfortable. <https://sdsbitmesra.in>

messages.text: Memes are fickle. They get old real quick, and there‚Äôs always a negative way they can be read

messages.text: I could see a political meme - such as having AOC saying to use Julia to reduce energy consumption, for example.

messages.text: If she were told some real facts about Julia (use of <http://Pumas.ai|Pumas.ai> by Moderna, and the Clima project, etc.) she might endorse it for real! :blush:

messages.text: Besides, are many people who believe in Trump likely to want to find something with such a scientific bent as Julia anyway? :thinking_face:

messages.text: As someone not at all related to the US (politics, state, all of it) - can we not use local politics as a means for anything here?

elements.text: As someone not at all related to the US (politics, state, all of it) - can we not use local politics as a means for anything here?

messages.text: One of my favorite things about this community is how little politics are discussed. It‚Äôs quite remarkable at times, which makes me think a lot of people appreciate that. So I guess yeah, even if it‚Äôs expected to be a harmless meme, probably best if PR steers as clear of politics as the community chat does

elements.text: One of my favorite things about this community is how little politics are discussed. It‚Äôs quite remarkable at times, which makes me think a lot of people appreciate that. So I guess yeah, even if it‚Äôs expected to be a harmless meme, probably best if PR steers as clear of politics as the community chat does

messages.text: I agree. I think it's important to recognize that not discussing politics is still political, though.

elements.text: I agree. I think it's important to recognize that not discussing politics is still political, though.

messages.text: It's in the same vein as the paradox of tolerance.

elements.text: It's in the same vein as the paradox of tolerance.

messages.text: FWIW, I don't think it is that important to recognize, it's fairly obvious what is meant with politics here and it should be easy to separate that from the policies the julia community itself implement.

elements.text: FWIW, I don't think it is that important to recognize, it's fairly obvious what is meant with politics here and it should be easy to separate that from the policies the julia community itself implement.

messages.text: It's among the same lines as saying "it is important to recognize that not allowing intolerant people is a limit of tolerance". Technically true, but irrelevant in practice.

elements.text: It's among the same lines as saying "it is important to recognize that not allowing intolerant people is a limit of tolerance". Technically true, but irrelevant in practice.

messages.text:
Yeah I was debating posting that comment. It's probably obvious for you, but for people who never think about politics that way (me as a teenager,  for instance) I think it's useful.

I'm aware that I am coming dangerously close to the edge of the "no politics" line here, but I also want to say that the statement "it is important to recognize that not allowing intolerant people is a limit of tolerance" is not the same. Discussing politics benefits marginalized people who stand to liberate themselves from changing the current politics.

So what I mean is, banning "politics" is really an implicit endorsement of the status quo and the people that benefit from maintaining it. If that is obvious to you, great, but I don't think it is for everyone.

elements.text:

I'm aware that I am coming dangerously close to the edge of the "no politics" line here, but I also want to say that the statement "it is important to recognize that not allowing intolerant people is a limit of tolerance" is not the same. Discussing politics benefits marginalized people who stand to liberate themselves from changing the current politics.

So what I mean is, banning "politics" is really an implicit endorsement of the status quo and the people that benefit from maintaining it. If that is obvious to you, great, but I don't think it is for everyone.

messages.text:
The reason this slack community has policies against political discussion is that the discussions that were happening were becoming increasingly unproductive, nasty and unwelcoming. 

The discussions happening had very little if any benefit to the wider world, but had a palpably negative effect on the health of the community and how welcoming it was to new members.

elements.text:
The reason this slack community has policies against political discussion is that the discussions that were happening were becoming increasingly unproductive, nasty and unwelcoming. 

The discussions happening had very little if any benefit to the wider world, but had a palpably negative effect on the health of the community and how welcoming it was to new members.

messages.text: There's a very specific kind of "politics" that I (personally) don't care for here, not least of which because I have no influence over it: US/any kind of government related politics. Not wanting to talk about things I can't influence at all is not the same as endorsing them.

elements.text: There's a very specific kind of "politics" that I (personally) don't care for here, not least of which because I have no influence over it: US/any kind of government related politics. Not wanting to talk about things I can't influence at all is not the same as endorsing them.

messages.text: "Politics" as it relates to how we, as a community, want to do things for us, is obviously not the in the same vein here - that doesn't mean that we have to bring in that other kind of politics though.

elements.text: "Politics" as it relates to how we, as a community, want to do things for us, is obviously not the in the same vein here - that doesn't mean that we have to bring in that other kind of politics though.

messages.text: Yes I agree, I was clarifying since I felt that <@U67D54KS8> did not properly characterize my comment in his reply.

elements.text: Yes I agree, I was clarifying since I felt that
did not properly characterize my comment in his reply.

messages.text: Well, no one is suggesting that you cannot discuss politics outside of the Julia platforms. It's not like the policy means that Kristoffer cannot endorse Trump on twitter for example. It just means that "our" (collectively as Julia users) slack/discourse is not the place to do it.

elements.text: Well, no one is suggesting that you cannot discuss politics outside of the Julia platforms. It's not like the policy means that Kristoffer cannot endorse Trump on twitter for example. It just means that "our" (collectively as Julia users) slack/discourse is not the place to do it.

attachments.text: Hello all! ¬°Saludos banda! I will be giving a brief 20 min-ish talk tomorrow in Spanish called ‚ÄúConsidering Julia‚Äù. It will be in Spanish, the link is below. I will be pre-recording a longer version (√° la JuliaCon) so that I can talk about the things I want without feeling rushed :smiley: This was in part facilitated by @categulario (not yet here) and @xalapacode, a Mexican local coding org. I will post a link to the youtube recording here once I‚Äôm done.

messages.text: At the point I am openning an issue, I say things like: _"X is hard to use. Can we add a option for Y, or should we improve the docs ..."_

elements.text: At the point I am openning an issue, I say things like: _"X is hard to use. Can we add a option for Y, or should we improve the docs ..."_

messages.text: I think it's good because it is non-confrontational. I am not saying "your thing is hard to use", I am making it clear that I want to collaborate to find a solution

messages.text: I personally feel it comes off a bit odd when someone brand new to a community starts "we"-ing straight away, especially when it is combined with strong opinions about moving the project in certain ways.

elements.text: I personally feel it comes off a bit odd when someone brand new to a community starts "we"-ing straight away, especially when it is combined with strong opinions about moving the project in certain ways.

messages.text: I always feel like I need to clarify the "we", am I talking as a member of the community, the JuliaLab, which subsection of the community (we === GPU folks, we === Julia Base) so I stick to I fairly often. I think ;)

elements.text: I always feel like I need to clarify the "we", am I talking as a member of the community, the JuliaLab, which subsection of the community (we === GPU folks, we === Julia Base) so I stick to I fairly often. I think ;)

messages.text: I would be  careful to put weight on these things, that‚Äôs quite influenced by mother tongue, strata etc

elements.text: I would be  careful to put weight on these things, that‚Äôs quite influenced by mother tongue, strata etc

messages.text: For example I often hear ‚Äúmi mama‚Äù (my mother) in Spanish even if one sibling talks to another sibling, which sounds very weird when your own language requires the use of ‚Äúour mother‚Äù in this situation
